awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  A Novel Self-Cleaning Microfiltration Membrane System for Water Purification
awd_abstract_narration:
1549736
Chen

Membrane filtration plays a critical role in advanced water and wastewater treatment practices. However, membrane fouling increases the operation and maintenance costs, and ultimately shortens membrane life. The main objective of this project is to explore the fundamental mechanisms of self-cleaning piezoelectric membrane systems and the application guidelines for fouling control. This project may greatly advance membrane filtration technology for water and wastewater treatment.

This study explores piezoelectric membranes to solve membrane fouling problems in filtration processes. Utilizing multi-functional piezoelectric membrane materials, the project will result in an innovative approach to control membrane fouling. This project is the first to systematically investigate the cleaning mechanisms of the piezoelectric membranes and the anti-fouling efficiency for common types of membrane foulants. Upon completion of this study, the project will reveal; 1) the fundamental cleaning mechanisms of the piezoelectric membranes; 2) the cleaning efficiency with respect to typical membrane foulants such as particles, organic matters and microorganism; 3) the cleaning effect with respect to cake layer formation vs. membrane pore blocking; 4) the technical guidelines of system optimization such as vibration frequency, waveform and amplitude; 5) surface modification of the piezoelectric membrane to be less prone to fouling and easier to clean; and, 6) potential side effects and how to avoid them. The fundamental research includes mechanics of vibration, sonochemistry, water chemistry, fluid mechanics, and disinfection. This research is potentially transformative as it may bring a revolutionary solution to membrane fouling and greatly advance the membrane filtration technology. The proposed membrane system has the advantages of being chemical-free, with cost-saving, a small footprint, productivity enhancement, extension of membrane life, and easy push-button operation. The proposed study is of great significance for both fundamental scientific research and industrial applications. In addition, this project will support the educational missions of the university as well, including courses development and support minority students in STEM education.

por.por_cntn:
Membrane filtration is receiving more and more acceptance in modern water and wastewater treatment processes. However, one of the main barriers to expanding use of membrane technologies is membrane fouling, in that membranes become dirty and clogged through use. As a result, membrane productivity declines significantly over time, which increases the energy used and cost of water filtration. This project explored a dynamic and self-cleaning piezoelectric membrane system, an innovative approach to mitigate membrane fouling. Different from a conventional membrane, which sits statically in a pressure vessel and is clogged passively, this project utilized a piezoelectric multi-functional material that can vibrate and serve as a membrane filter simultaneously. More specifically, porous polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membranes vibrate at controlled frequencies, amplitudes, and durations. Vibration cleans and removes impurities from membrane’s surface and pores. As a result, the membrane can be kept clean to produce purified water at a high capacity for a relatively long time. This membrane system has the advantages such as chemical-free, cost-saving, small footprint, productivity enhancement, extension of membrane life, and easy push-button operation.

The project systematically investigated the cleaning mechanisms and the efficiency of piezoelectric membranes to reduce fouling caused by suspended kaolin particles, a common type of membrane foulants. Among different PVDF films, the one of the highest content of beta-phase PVDF was selected for filtration because of the greatest piezoelectric coefficient. The characteristic peaks of vibration velocity and amplitude were identified by measurements of a Scanning Laser-Doppler vibrometer with tiered driving voltages. The piezoelectric membrane was tested in a dead-end membrane cell fed with 0.5 g/L kaolin suspension of 907.7 nm Z-average diameter at a constant filtration pressure of 34.5 kPa. For the first time, it has been found that vibration velocity is more important than amplitude to choose the vibration frequency in order to optimize membrane cleaning. The piezoelectric membrane with continued vibration driven by 24 V (peak-to-peak) and sine wave at the frequency of 1601 Hz (the peak of vibration velocity) yielded 87±3% higher permeate flux than the control tests (i.e. without vibration), compared to 30±3% increase at the frequency of 664 Hz (the peak of vibration amplitude). However, the antifouling effect was not apparent with intermittent vibration, possibly due to interrupted processes of cleaning and fouling prevention. The mechanistic explanation of cleaning suggests the lift force brought by hydraulic shearing is more important than inertial lift force of vibration for membrane fouling control.

This fundamental research has provided an effective solution to fight membrane fouling and to improve the filtration performance. The applications of the results from this research may lead to many practical benefits to the science communities and water and wastewater treatment industries. More specifically, below are three major broader impacts of this project.

1. Support the scientific research and water and wastewater treatment industries

This study initiated a new research area of combining water filtration technology and the science of piezoelectric material. The project resulted in an innovative approach for control of membrane fouling. As a result, a long-lasting, less fouling, and cost-saving membrane filtration technology may be further developed to provide safer and more affordable clean water. In addition, this project provided a better understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of using piezoelectric membranes for membrane fouling control. Based on this project, one oral and one poster presentation were delivered to American Chemical Society research conferences; in addition, a manuscript was submitted for journal publication.

2. Integration of research and education

This project employed two undergraduate students to conduct the research activities. In addition, four undergraduate students used this project as their capstone senior design. The students involved in this study have been systematically trained with fundamental scientific knowledge and research skills from theoretical, experimental, and analytical aspects. Furthermore, the PI featured this project in teaching Environmental Engineering courses, and in an outreach activity by demonstrating and introducing drinking water treatment techniques and processes to general public in the Science Central Museum in Fort Wayne, Indiana.

3. Support the diversity and the minority of the society

One of the two undergraduate assistants hired for this project was female. The research activities of this project provided valuable opportunities for the underrepresented groups to succeed in their education and future careers.
